channel.title: I'm just wondering
channel.description:
Okay so I'm a freshman in high school and we was goin over stuff in algebra and I noticed that there are some statements in algebra that are the same in c++ and java... such as
if - then statements variables integers doubles
and one that I had seen in programming before but never really understood what it meant and so I was wondering if "Null" meant the same in algebra as it does in programming, because in algebra a null set is when the answer does not match with one of the "pre-set" variables like
{2,3,4,5}
x = 4
2x - 2
the answer would then be NULL (or something close to that equation)
so in programming is a "null" an answer that doesnt match up with the "pre-set" variables? I just kinda wanted to know because I didn't really understand "NULL"
also how would you make the "NULL SET" symbol on a keyboard, and if you can make it, can you then use that in a program?

item.title: I'm just wondering

item.description:
@_Vengeance wrote:

If something has a null value, it means it has no value. And theres a reason why a lot of stuff in algebra turns up in programming…
